awd_titl_txt: Function Space Trend Determination using Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Trends are found everywhere in socio-economic discourse about economic growth, inequality, welfare, and economic disparities across regions and nations. They play an important role in much economic theory and other areas of scientific research. Methods of trend determination have been intensively studied in economics for a long time, yet economists have little guidance on the source and nature of trend behavior and therefore rely on a limited class of models to use in applications. This research program will explore a new approach to studying trends that involves modern machine learning methods. The goal is to model trends when there is little practical or theoretical guidance about the nature of the trending behavior. Methods will be developed to learn about trends in a general function space environment that will enable wide application to study socio-economic phenomena. These methods will be useful in other scientific fields, such as climate change, where trends figure prominently. 

The project will develop and analyze an easy-to-implement machine learning procedure that enhances the properties of existing methods of smoothing and filtering data. The central idea is to iterate such filters in a controlled manner to make them a smarter smoothing device for trend determination. This approach involves methods of machine learning based on boosting and the project will develop the necessary theory to justify their application to non-stationary data that manifest trend behavior. In particular, the project will develop a large sample limit theory for boosted filters that will reveal its enhanced capabilities, focusing on the complex task of analyzing properties of the boosting methodology in the context of non-stationary data characterized by deterministic and stochastic trends allowing also for possible structural breaks. The resulting theory will be applicable to a wide class of underlying processes, thereby facilitating informed use of such machine learning devices in practical work in economics and other disciplines where trend determination is needed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Prominent features of economic and financial data include the presence of  trends and cyclical tendencies. Trends reflect longer term movements in technology, capital, and demographics that influence aggregate economic activity. Fluctuations in this activity over shorter periods are commonly known as business cycles, although in recent decades these fluctations have become irregular and often longer lasting. To analyze trends and business cycles in observed data it is necessary to employ a statistical methodology that helps to isolate the trend movements from other behavior in the data.This decomposition is commonly achieved by regression methods or by simple filtering techniques. This NSF supported project designed new econometric techniques that developed modern machine learning mechanisms to enhance the properites of commonly used filtering methods that smooth the data in attempting to isolate trend growth. A primary outcome of the research identifies the tendency of existing methods to oversmooth economic data and provides a clear mathematical representation of this shortcoming. A secondary outcome of the research developed a machine learning boosting procedure that corrects oversmoothing in existing methods and delivers a consistent new estimate of the underlying trend process. An associated development is the extension of the methodology to allow for a wide range of stochastically trending behavior that accommodates important time series such as interest rates and unemployment. A further outcome concerns the development of new methods for the use of functional data in applied economic research.  This type of data arises in spatial frameworks of trade and migration in economic geography or in labor market studies that deal with lifetime income curves. 

Research in these three areas involved the econometric techniques that form the foundation for understanding how the methods work and can be applied in practical work of estimation and inference. To illustrate the use of the new methods, substantial empirical work was conducted and reported in the published articles. Some of this applied research used large datasets for many countries that enabled international business cycle analysis for emergent and developed economies. Other work focused on the US economy, studying trends and cycles in industrial production, unemployment rates and inflation. The major outcomes from these empirical studies affirmed the usefulness of careful implementation of filtering methods that are capable of adjustment to the stochastic character of most of the trends and cycles that occur in economic and financial data. The boosting methods, in particular, were shown to have singular advantages in this respect over simple autoregressive methods that are commonly used to study macroeconomic time series.  

Over the period of this NSF project from September 2019, the PI has supervised or co-supervised 11 doctoral students to completion. Several of these students have worked on aspects of the project with the PI. 

Research on the project is presently ongoing and not all aspects of the planned work have been completed. Some delays arising from lockdowns and illness of the PI and co-authors occured during the Covid pandemic and particularly affected joint research with co-authors. The PI was successful in requesting a no cost extension for one year but the PI's request for a second no cost extension was rejected.
